metadata.sermon_start_end: Pentecost, fifty days after Easter, is the one day each year in which Presbyterians imagine that we are open to God’s Spirit. We confess, after we say, “Father and Son” in the creed, “I believe in the Holy Spirit.” And then we name the gifts of the Spirit [...] People who are breathed on can live differently!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific Bible passage. It treats Psalm 104 as a thematic springboard, then jumps to Gospel narratives and Galatians. It does not identify what is unique to Psalm 104 that cannot be found elsewhere; instead, it harmonizes the text into general biblical themes.
quotes: For this Pentecost Sunday, we are given, along with the usual narrative texts, Psalm 104...
That work of taming chaos is done by the abiding Spirit of Jesus.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Psalm or the John passage. Identify the specific 'uniqueness' of the chosen text rather than using it as a hook for a general talk on the Spirit.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic awareness of the Hebrew worldview regarding the sea (Leviathan/chaos), but it is superficial. The preacher quickly moves to Christianizing the text without wrestling with the original context of the Psalm as a creation hymn.
quotes: People in the Bible always viewed the ocean as a scary threat, as a symbol of chaos...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegesis of Psalm 104. Explore the specific theology of creation and dependence in the Hebrew context before jumping to the New Testament.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is largely general and abstract. Mentioning 'Asians and Latinos' or 'commercial processes' provides a veneer of concreteness, but the spiritual application remains vague ('live in confidence', 'live differently'). It lacks the sharp cultural analysis Dekker demands.
quotes: We confess that we have food ... through all the complexity of commercial processes...
People who are breathed on can live differently!
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Address specific contemporary 'misery' or 'chaos'—such as a specific political crisis or psychological state—rather than listing general categories of people.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a rigid three-point structure where the text is quoted and then immediately 'translated' into a general truth. The hearer is not drawn into the movement of the text itself, but rather observes the preacher's thematic associations.
quotes: I. The Psalmist sings... The word at Pentecost is...
II. In the next verses the Psalmist marvels... Israel, in its faith, is aware...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'point-by-point' thematic structure. Let the exposition of the text's own logic drive the application simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The elements are present but 'soft'. Misery is described as 'chaos' or 'famine', but it lacks the depth of man's misery before God. Redemption is presented as a reliable 'iron lung', which borders on a mechanical view of grace rather than a personal-trinitarian one.
quotes: Without this life-giving force, we are hopeless and helpless, and the world will die.
God is like a great iron lung, reliable, paced, regular, life-giving.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect. Instead of 'chaos' as an external threat, address the internal lostness of the hearer.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is almost entirely absent. The sermon assumes a universal 'well-being' and 'provision'. There is no sense of the narrow way or the possibility of being lost. The tone is one of general reassurance.
quotes: The news is that the world works because the breath-giving God is present among us every minute of all creation.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the 'two ways'. What happens if one does not 'receive the Holy Spirit'? The sermon needs the tension of human responsibility.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned frequently as the 'telos', which aligns with Dekker. However, the connection often feels forced (reading Jesus back into the Psalm) rather than Christ emerging as the fulfillment of the specific text's promise.
quotes: That work of taming chaos is done by the abiding Spirit of Jesus.
All this we have seen in Jesus...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how Christ specifically fulfills the unique promise of the text, rather than using Him as a general 'solution' to the themes raised.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 950 words, the sermon would last less than 10 minutes. According to Dekker/Miskotte, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for theological depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the sermon significantly to at least 20 minutes (approx. 2000 words) to allow for genuine exposition and concrete application.

overall_assessment.summary: The text functions more as a thematic devotional talk than a sermon according to Dekker's criteria. It lacks a single scriptural focus, is significantly too short, and avoids the 'two ways' of human destination. While it attempts to be Christocentric, it does so by harmonizing disparate texts rather than deep exposition of one.
strengths: Clear trinitarian structure (Father/Creator, Son/Redeemer, Spirit/Giver of life).
Attempts to link biblical imagery (Leviathan, Bread) to the person of Jesus.
Avoids overly sentimental language, maintaining a focus on God's objective action in the world.
weaknesses: Length: At under 10 minutes, it cannot achieve the necessary homiletical depth.
Lack of specificity: It treats the Bible as a collection of general ideas rather than a specific, current Word.
Absence of the 'Two Ways': There is no sense of urgency or the gravity of being lost; it is a sermon of pure affirmation without the 'crisis' of the Gospel.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a brief thematic address that fails the formal requirement of 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage' and the substantive requirement of 'depth needs breadth'.
